nodes.text: We can align investments with basic human rights using professional, benchmark-aware implementation. Large institutions already use narrowly scoped exclusions while maintaining diversification and risk controls.
For friends or family, emphasize aligning personal savings with shared values and keep the steps concrete and jargon-free.
Individual investors can align personal or household savings with their values using low-cost screened funds while keeping diversification and emergency reserves intact.
A sovereign fund can implement conduct-based exclusions via a formal ethics process, public rationales, and factor-neutral optimization with explicit tracking-error budgets.
Public pensions can adopt a clear exclusion policy with consultant support, preserve diversification, and report progress without sacrificing fiduciary discipline.
Public plans can use consultant/manager mandates, set a tracking-error guardrail, and phase implementation while keeping beneficiaries’ risk/return in focus.
Corporate plans can update the IPS, adopt a screened index or constraints with minimal overhead, and maintain de-risking alignment.
An endowment can reflect mission and educational values with transparent criteria and periodic reviews.
Endowments can align with mission through a committee process, publish rationales, and maintain prudent risk controls.
Foundations can align programs and portfolios, reduce reputational risk through clear criteria, and use simplified implementation paths.
Insurance portfolios can adopt narrow conduct screens consistent with ALM and capital/rating constraints, emphasizing best-efforts and risk integrity.
Official institutions can clarify mandate limits, apply best-efforts exclusions, and provide transparent rationales and constraints.
For government bond portfolios, define approved issuer lists and issuer screens consistent with procurement rules and transparency.
Government investors (city/county/state) can apply issuer screens/approved lists for bonds, observe procurement/governance limits, and report with best-efforts language.

nodes.claim: The board doesn't have authority to make investment decisions.
nodes.response: Boards set policy; staff and consultants implement. UC Regents and other fiduciary boards codify exclusions in IPS language while delegating execution to investment teams under defined tracking-error limits.

nodes.claim: This is virtue signaling that won't change anything.
nodes.response: Our clients' signals become shared policy. Every valid alert we receive is researched and added to firm-wide exclusions, and our flagship growth strategy has matched MSCI ACWI while staying values-aligned—so the work is both communal and financially credible.

nodes.claim: We need engagement, not divestment.
nodes.response: Escalation ladders work: institutions like the Church of England and Danish pensions engage first, set time-bound objectives, and divest when companies fail to remedy violations—preserving credibility and risk discipline.

nodes.claim: What about China/Saudi Arabia/other countries?
nodes.response: Apply one standard everywhere: our policy covers any issuer implicated in grave violations—Israeli, Chinese, American, or otherwise—using international law and third-party evidence as triggers.

nodes.claim: This politicizes our investment process.
nodes.response: Ignoring credible violations is itself a political stance. We use ethical screening as an active risk-management decision—protecting portfolios from legal, reputational, and stranded-asset exposure identified in our screening policy.

nodes.response: Even small revenue lines can signal structural risk: Caterpillar and Israeli banks face lawsuits, exclusions, and credit pressure tied to settlement activity. Screening reallocates capital to resilient issuers.

nodes.claim: How do we define 'settlement involvement'?
nodes.response: Use objective sources: UN databases, AFSC Investigate, and vendor ESG datasets itemize settlement-linked projects. Policies trigger off this evidence and require periodic review.

nodes.response: Set cadence and delegate: many policies mandate annual reviews plus event-driven updates fed by third-party alerts. Consultants and managers absorb the monitoring, reporting back through dashboards.

nodes.response: Ask for transparency about current constraints. Managers already deliver exclusion mandates; mainstream ESG providers offer screened benchmarks, and active oversight keeps implementation honest even when broad-market funds remain.

nodes.claim: MSCI or Sustainability ratings are more credible than activist data.
nodes.response: We build proprietary screens because mainstream ratings are inconsistent and often influenced by commercial incentives. Specialist intelligence (AFSC, UN) identifies issues faster, and we overlay that insight with widely-used index tools for transparent delivery.

nodes.claim: This sets dangerous precedent for future exclusions.
nodes.response: Institutions already manage multiple ethical screens. UTS and SFSU frame new exclusions as extensions of long-standing SRI policies, proving conduct standards can evolve while staying disciplined.

nodes.claim: Our endowment/foundation documents prohibit political positions.
nodes.response: Conduct-based policies focus on fiduciary risk, not partisan statements. UC Regents' guidelines and UTS's SRI history show boards can codify exclusions as part of their duty to manage reputational and legal risk.

nodes.claim: We're a global institution serving diverse stakeholders.
nodes.response: Global fiduciaries already run conduct screens. NBIM and KLP manage worldwide portfolios while excluding companies tied to occupation abuses, demonstrating universal standards work at scale.

nodes.label: Free Money Podcast: Divestment Without Dissonance
nodes.citationText: Free Money Podcast. (2023, May 19). Divestment without dissonance [Audio podcast]. https://freemoneypodcast.com/p/divestment-without-dissonance

nodes.claim: The situation is too complex for binary decisions.
nodes.response: Policies can blend process and precision. Evergreen State College defused protests by launching a task force, while Free Money highlights that continued dialogue about ethics and finance is itself part of responsible governance.

nodes.claim: This undermines academic freedom and exchange.
nodes.response: Universities exist for inquiry. Ashby Monk and Kelly Grotke highlight that divestment conversations deepen learning and institutional character; policies can target financial holdings while protecting academic collaboration.

nodes.claim: We lack precedent from peer institutions.
nodes.response: Peer action is growing: institutions from SFSU to Union Theological Seminary and pension giants like KLP have adopted universal human-rights screens. They communicate the policy as a continuity of existing SRI principles.

nodes.claim: This distracts from our core mission.
nodes.response: Mission and finance are intertwined. The Free Money conversation notes divestment debates deepen understanding of finance's role, while campuses like SFSU tailored policies that supported student learning without derailing institutional objectives.

nodes.citationText: MSCI. (n.d.). ESG index construction methodology. https://www.msci.com/our-solutions/indexes/esg-indexes

nodes.claim: Divestment will significantly hurt performance and beneficiaries.
nodes.response: Naive exclusions can be costly, but professional managers use optimization and tracking-error limits to preserve factor exposures and benchmark-like returns.

nodes.citationText: Principles for Responsible Investment. (2019). Fiduciary duty in the 21st century. https://www.unpri.org/fiduciary-duty

nodes.claim: Exclusions violate fiduciary duty.
nodes.response: Fiduciary duty requires prudence, loyalty, and attention to material risk and client objectives. Values alignment and risk management can be implemented within a disciplined, return-seeking mandate.

nodes.label: Oxford SSEE Research
nodes.citationText: University of Oxford, Smith School of Enterprise and the Environment. (n.d.). Sustainable finance research. https://www.smithschool.ox.ac.uk/research/sustainable-finance

nodes.claim: Divestment is ineffective; someone else just buys the shares.
nodes.response: The primary effects are reputational and in primary capital markets. Policies influence lenders, underwriters, and index providers and shift the cost of capital for targeted issuers.

nodes.label: MSCI Portfolio Construction
nodes.citationText: MSCI. (n.d.). Portfolio construction solutions. https://www.msci.com/our-solutions/indexes/esg-indexes

nodes.claim: Exclusions reduce diversification too much.
nodes.response: Well-designed policies are narrow and conduct-based. Managers maintain diversification across sectors and factors while removing a limited set of issuers that breach defined standards.

nodes.claim: Our index funds can't accommodate exclusions.
nodes.response: Major providers offer screened versions of core indexes, and mandates can overlay exclusion lists via optimization. Public pensions already run Israel/settlement screens inside benchmark-aware vehicles.

nodes.claim: Israeli companies provide essential technology/services.
nodes.response: A conduct-first policy distinguishes between legitimate business and grave rights violations. Exclusions target companies whose revenue or technology is tied to occupation abuses; suppliers meeting standards remain investable.

nodes.label: SSRN: Impact of ESG Rating Changes
nodes.citationText: Luo, R., & Balvers, R. (2021). Socially responsible investing with ESG rating dynamics. SSRN. https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3722087

nodes.claim: UN databases are politically motivated and unreliable.
nodes.response: Treat activist research as the specialist edge. Ground-level groups like AFSC or the UN database track evidence sooner than generalized ESG vendors; large funds (e.g., KLP) use them as the investigative spine and apply mainstream index tools for implementation.

nodes.claim: Apartheid divestment was chaos; why repeat it?
nodes.response: Apartheid divestment proved you can stand on ethics without breaking returns. Our firm’s policy embraces that precedent: we run apartheid-free portfolios with documented process and rely on sustained, multi-channel pressure—divestment plus engagement—just as history shows.

nodes.claim: How do you know these activist lists aren't biased?
nodes.response: We do not outsource ethics to third-party lists. About 40% of our exclusions are unique because we rebuild evidence in-house and document every call; activist data is an input, not the final answer.

nodes.claim: This sounds expensive or complicated—where do I even start?
nodes.response: Ethical screening is messy in practice—that’s why investors hire professionals to map the evidence, translate it into exclusions, and keep the process on track.

nodes.title: Model Resolution
nodes.markdown:
RESOLVED: That the {localName} shall adopt a conduct-based investment exclusion policy, instructing its investment managers to avoid purchasing or holding securities of companies for which there is credible, public evidence of severe human rights violations, including complicity in violations under international humanitarian law; and be it further

RESOLVED: That the {localName} directs its investment managers to implement this policy using professional portfolio construction techniques that maintain diversification and risk controls, including explicit tracking error limits relative to the benchmark; and be it further

RESOLVED: That the {localName} will publish an exclusion rationale and a public list of excluded issuers, reviewed at least annually; and be it further

RESOLVED: That the {localName} will phase implementation over an orderly period and report progress and holdings, subject to prudent trading and confidentiality constraints.

nodes.title: Government Policy Template
nodes.markdown:
Approved Issuers Policy (template)

Purpose: Maintain an Approved Issuers List for fixed-income investing that aligns treasury practices with ethical standards and risk controls while complying with law and procurement rules.

Criteria: Exclude issuers with credible, public evidence of severe human rights violations (including complicity in violations under international humanitarian law). Consider authoritative sources (sanctions lists, court decisions, official investigations) and reputable human-rights reporting.

Portfolio Constraints: Preserve target duration, credit quality, liquidity, and diversification consistent with the investment policy and statutes.

Process: Treasurer (or designee) maintains Approved and Prohibited Issuer lists; legal/procurement review; annual review and event-driven updates; exceptions require written rationale, legal review, time limits, and notification to the governing body.

Transparency & Reporting: Publish criteria and current lists subject to prudent trading and confidentiality; report changes and rationales at least annually.

Compliance: This policy operates subject to state law, investment statutes, and procurement rules; in case of conflict, legal requirements prevail.

nodes.title: CIO Implementation Note
nodes.markdown: Implementation focuses on preserving benchmark alignment: specify a tracking-error budget, maintain factor neutrality, use vendor screened indexes or optimization constraints, and phase trades to avoid divestment shocks.
